title: Re: Ebay
content:
No, but it is a really good store. Ebay just rocks: today, my dad bought WinDVD 4 for only $0.01!!! The computer I am using is a Thinkpad 770ED, and was worth 6k new!!! It is a think media laptop, and was made for watching DVD's, listening to music, and playing games. It was a power-house of it's times!

We updated from Win95 to Win98SE (So I could use a memory stick), and lost our DVD decoders in the proscess. We should be getting them with the WinDVD.

I, personally, have bought a lot on Ebay:

I got standees, posters, legos, and much more... but I am not addicted to eBay.Tough Guys Can Fix Their Own Problems!!!

content: I might be if the shipping and handling wouldn't be so gargin' expensive. Until it S&H gets way cheaper I'll use one Finnish auction.Eat your veggies!

title: Re: Ebay
content: Umm... exactly what would you need a huge 19" Sun rack for? (Unless it's a work purchase, or you live in a datacenter.)

title: Re: Ebay
content:
What do you mean 'try'? [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-cheeky.gif[/img] It's worked perfectly ever since [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img]

That link above is a server rack - basically a spiffy form of shelving, specifically designed to hold computer gear. I got it because I'm tired of having all my computers piled up all over the floor and it's a nice geeky way of tidying things up. It looks pretty impressive once it's filled up with computers. I'll have to post a photo of it one day...

title: Re: Ebay
content:
I've never trusted eBay for computer/technology-related purchases since I managed to buy about $100 of individual parts that didn't work. Serves me right for not scrutinizing the item description close enough, I guess. Anyway, I've seen few components on eBay that were significantly cheaper than new retail parts.[url=http://www.toxicsheep.com]www.toxicsheep.com[/url]
[url=http://www.last.fm/user/grafix5000/][img]http://www.toxicsheep.com/sigs/scrobblersig.php[/img][/url]

title: Re: Ebay
content: A lot of people seem to say that, but I've only had a few dud things off eBay and most of the time the sellers accepted them back and gave me a refund.  Not that it matters any more, since eBay offers all that buyer protection which should stop it from happening.

title: Re: Ebay
content:
Haha, nice find Malvineous! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-dexter.gif[/img]

I remember Spleen bought a pickup truck full of olde computers once from eBay.. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] Eat your veggies!

title: spleenBuy
content:
I'm not addicted to it, but it's almost as big a part of my life right now as the PCKF. One of my current projects is building some of those computers I bought last year into ber tweaked oldschool beasts and selling them off cheap. Some of them will be designed for DOS gaming, others as SOHO machines (it's amazing what you can still do with a P200 with a tweaked out Win9[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-dexter.gif[/img] .

Most of those machines didn't come with HDDs so I'm buying as many < 40Gb drives as I can. It's amazing how many people pay excessive prices for such small drives though.

One of my more tasty purchases was for 16 20" CRT monitors, at a total of $610.22 including postage. They're bloody heavy, but they work damn nice. And they sell for around $100 each. The funny thing is, after using such massive screens for a couple of weeks, 15" monitors start to look more and more like toys every time I walk past one. [edited: paragraph was broken]

[hr]Malvineous I got it because I'm tired of having all my computers piled up all over the floor and it's a nice geeky way of tidying things up.
[hr]Gah. Ebay refuses to load on my dodgebox connection at the moment. I like the sound of that rack, though. I'm hoping to build one sometime soon, with space for maybe 10 PCs and a built-in switch. As it stands I find it difficult to have more than four computers setup in my shed without running out of space.

[hr]Malvineous A lot of people seem to say that, but I've only had a few dud things off eBay and most of the time the sellers accepted them back and gave me a refund.
[hr]Likewise. As long as you keep an eye on sellers' feedback scores, I've found that people are generally quite reasonable when it comes to faulty products and such. Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

[url=http://jimsoft.spatang.com/]JimSoft Lair[/url]

title: Re: spleenBuy
content:
Interesting ideas you have for your 'old' PCs - I'm still intending to get all mine set up in the rack and use them as a Linux cluster. I find it very difficult to sell anything that still works... [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

"One of my more tasty purchases was for 16 20" CRT monitors"

Wow, that must've been one big shipment. Mind you, at least you could carry it up stairs - when the rack arrived it weighed 225kg so it was rather tricky carrying it up a flight of stairs to my front door...

"after using such massive screens for a couple of weeks, 15" monitors start to look more and more like toys"

Heh, with a 19" and a 21" monitor on my main PC, I know exactly what you mean - it's amazing how quickly you get used to the size.

title: Re: spleenBuy
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr] I'm still intending to get all mine set up in the rack and use them as a Linux cluster.[hr][/quote]
I'd ask what you plan to use that for, except I know that's not the point. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

[quote]Quote:[hr]after using such massive screens for a couple of weeks, 15" monitors start to look more and more like toys[hr][/quote]
Yeah, same here. I can't imagine working on a tiny monitor anymore. Or at less than 1600x1200 resolution for that matter.________________

Yes, I hate using computers stuck as low as 1024x768 now - both my monitors are 1600x1200 too, giving me a 3200x1200 pixel desktop [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-drool.gif[/img]
